comments.body: not a fan of the aligned assignments (is that a pep8 thing? I'm not really a python guy)
@goozbach Yes. It is to match Ansible module standards.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +151,155 @@
    # global vars
    changed = False
    msgs = []
    configfile = module.params['configfile']

comments.body: Putting the `changed = True` here means that changes will not be reported every time the module is run. Instead, I set `reboot_required` and return that as an indicator that the system needs a reboot. This may not be desirable and I'm open to suggestions.

Seems reasonable. It is always better to have info like this (a flag to indicate the system needs reboot) as predictable structured data so that automation can act on it reliably. Previously this would have to have been parsed out of the msgs (or more likely, the msg was rarely noticed...) so that is an improvement.

If someone was parsing the message, the msg change might break it, but structured data and a better error message is üëç for me

                changed = True
        else:
            module.warn("Reboot is required to set SELinux state to %s" % state)
